properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong thunderstorms late Saturday followed by significant rainfall on Sunday. A significant change in the weather will arrive on Saturday as a low pressure system enters B.C. from Washington State. Ahead of the low Saturday afternoon, atmospheric conditions will be conducive to potentially strong thunderstorms with frequent lightning and very strong wind gusts. Heavy rain is also likely with these storms. Widespread rainfall will accompany the low pressure system Saturday night and Sunday, and will cause local rivers to rise. Environment and Climate Change Canada meteorologists will continue to monitor the situation. For more information on river flow forecasts, and flood warning and advisories, please visit the BC River Forecast Centre website at http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-30T15:42:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-29T23:43:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0858806210.2020
Area: South Thompson, Nicola, Similkameen, North Okanagan - including Vernon, Central Okanagan - including Kelowna, South Okanagan - including Penticton, Shuswap, Arrow Lakes - Slocan Lake, Boundary, West Kootenay, Kootenay Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Temperatures will fall to the freezing mark tonight across many areas in south-central and south-eastern Manitoba. An Arctic high will send temperatures well below seasonal values tonight with widespread low temperatures of -1 to +1C. Frost is possible across much of the region tonight, although will be most likely in the southern Interlake into southeastern Manitoba. In the Red River Valley, temperatures will remain warmest near the western escarpment where lows will likely fall to the 0 to +1C range. Towards the Red River, frost becomes more likely, then becomes probable east of the Red River. In Winnipeg, frost is likely in open and outlying regions, however areas closer to the core will likely remain above freezing. Even in areas that will generally remain above freezing across southern Manitoba, isolated patches of frost will be possible in low-lying areas or areas cold air drainage. Temperatures will recover early Saturday morning, followed by a general warming trend over the coming days. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-05-30T12:29:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-05-29T20:30:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2134636756.2020
